DIV1.P: THE CASTLE SPECTRE: A DRAMA. IN Five Acts.
BY M. G. LEWIS, ESQ. M. P. AUTHOR OF "THE MONK," &c.
NOW PERFORMING WITH UNBOUNDED APPLAUSE AT THE Theatre in Boston.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: NEVER tell me!—I repeat it, you are a fel∣low of a very scandalous course of life!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: And I repeat it, I'm a perfect image of the purest virtue, compared to whom, for sobriety and continence, Ca∣to was a drunkard, and Lucretia little better than she should be.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Oh! hardened in impudence!—Can you deny being a pilferer, a liar, a glutton—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Can I?—Heaven be thanked, I've courage enough to deny any thing!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Doesn't all the world cry out upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Certainly my transcendant merit has procured me some enemies; and, in common with many other great men, my virtue at present labours under something of a cloud. But understand me right, Father: Though I don't assent to the sum-total of your accusations, possibly I may acknowledge some of the items; the best actions frequently appear culpa∣ble, merely because their motives are unexplained. There∣fore produce your charges, let me justify my conduct, and I doubt not I shall retrieve my reputation from your hands as immaculate and pure as a new sheet of foolscap.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: To begin then with your pilfering—did you, or did you not, break open the pantry-door, and steal out the great goose-pye?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Begging your pardon, Father, that was no fault of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Whose then?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: The cook's, undoubtedly; for if he hadn't locked the pantry-door, 'tis an hundred to one I shouldn't have taken the trouble to break it open.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Nonsense! Nonsense!—I tell you, you've been guilty of stealing, which is a monstrous crime! And what did you steal? Had you taken any thing else, I might have forgiven you: but to lay irreverent hands upon the goose-pye!—As I'm a Christian, the identical goose-pye which I intended for my own supper!—But this is not my only objection to your conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: No?

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: What principally offends me is, that you per∣vert the minds of the maids, and keep kissing and smuggling all the pretty girls you meet. Oh, fye! fye!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: I kiss and smuggle them? St. Francis forbid! Lord love you, Father, 'tis they who kiss and smuggle me. I protest I do what I can to preserve my modesty; and I wish that Archbishop Dunstan had heard the lecture upon chastity which I read last night to the dairy-maid in the dark! he'd have been quite edified. But yet what does talking signify? The eloquence of my lips is counteracted by the lustre of my eyes; and really the little devils are so tender, and so troublesome, that I'm half angry with nature for hav∣ing made me so very bewitching.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Nonsense! Nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Why it was but yesterday that Cicely and Luce went to fifty-cuffs, quarrelling which looked neatest, my red leg, or my yellow one. Then they are so fond and so coax∣ing! They hang about one so lovingly! And one says, "Kind Mr. Motley!" and t'other, "Sweet Mr. Mot∣ley!"—Ah! Father Philip! Father Philip! How is a poor little bit of flesh and blood, like me, to resist such temp∣tation?—Put yourself in my place: Suppose that a sweet smiling rogue, just sixteen, with rosy cheeks, sparkling eyes, pouting lips, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Oh, fye! fye! fye!—To hear such licentious discourse, brings the tears into my eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: I believe you, Father; for I see the water is run∣ning over at your mouth. However, this shews you—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: It shews me that you are a reprobate, and that my advice is thrown away upon you: In future, I shall keep those counsels to myself, which I offered you from motives of pure Christian charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Charity, my good Father, should always begin at home: Now, instead of giving yourself so much trouble to mend me, what if you thought a little of correcting yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: I?—I have nothing to correct.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: No, to be sure!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: The odour of my sanctity perfumes the whole kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: It has a powerful smell about it, I own, not un∣like carrion; you may wind it a mile off.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: All malice!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Not exactly: I could mention some little points which might be altered in you still better than in myself; such as intemperance, gluttony—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Gluttony?—Oh! abominable falsehood!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Plain matter of fact!—Why will any man pretend to say that you came honestly by that enormous belly, that tremendous tomb of fish, flesh and fowl? I protest I'm grate∣ful to Heaven, that among the unclean beasts who accompani∣ed Noah, there went not into the ark a pair of fat monks: they must infallibly have created a famine, and then the world would never have been re-peopled. Next, for incon∣tinence, you must allow yourself that you are unequalled.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: I? I?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: You, you. May I ask what was your business in the beech-grove the other evening, when I caught you with buxom Margery the miller's pretty wife? Was it quite necessary to lay your heads together so close?

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Perfectly necessary: I was whispering in her ear wholesome advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Indeed? Faith, then she took your advice as kindly as it was given, and exactly in the same way too: you gave it with your lips, and she took it with her's!—Well done, Father Philip!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Son, son, you give your tongue too great a li∣cense.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Nay, Father, be not angry: Fools, you know, are privild persons.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: I know they are very useless ones: and in short, Master Motley, to be plain with you, of all fools, I think you the worst; and for fools of all kinds I've an in∣superable aversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P:
Really? Then you have one good quality at least,
and I cannot but admire such a total want of self-love! [A horn sounds.] But hark! 'tis the dinner horn. Away to ta∣ble, Father—Depend upon't, the servants will rather eat part of their dinner unblessed, than stay till your stomach comes, like Jonas's whale, and swallows up the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Well, well, fool, I am going: but first let me explain to you, that my bulk proceeds from no indulgence of voracious appetite: No, son, no. Little sustenance do I take; but St. Cuthbert's blessing is upon me, and that little prospers with me most marvellously. Verily, the saint has given me rather too plentiful an increase, and my legs are scarce able to support the weight of his bounties.

He looks like an overgrown turtle, wad∣dling upon its hind fins! Yet at bottom 'tis a good fellow enough, warm-hearted, benevolent, friendly, and sincere; but no more intended by nature to be a monk, than I to be a maid of honour to the Queen of Sheba.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: I cannot be mistaken: in spite of his dress, his features are too well known to me. Hist! Gilbert! Gilbert!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Gilbert? Oh Lord, that's I!—Who calls?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Have you forgotten me?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Truly, Sir, that would be no easy matter: I never forgot in my life what I never knew.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Have ten years altered me so much that you can∣not—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Hey!—Can it be—Pardon, my dear master, pardon! In truth, you may well forgive my having forgotten your name, for at first I didn't very well remember my own. However, to prevent further mistakes, I must inform you, that he who in your father's service was Gilbert the knave, is Motley the fool in the service of Earl Osmond.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Of Earl Osmond? This is fortunate. Gilbert, you may be of use to me; and if the attachment which as a boy you professed for me still exits.—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P:
It does with ardes unabated; for I'm not so un∣just as to attribute to you my expulsion from Alnwic Castle. In fact, I deserved it; for I cannot deny but that at twenty I was as good-for-nothing a knave as ever existed; conse∣quently old Earl Percy dismissed me from his service, but I know that it was sorely against your inclination. You were
then scarce fourteen, and I had been your companion and play-fellow from your childhood. I remember well your grief at parting with me, and that you slipped into my hand the purse which contained the whole of your little treasure. That act of kindness struck to my heart: I swore at the moment to love you through life, and if ever I forget my oath, damn me!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: My honest Gilbert!—And what made you as∣sume this habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Ah, my Lord! what could I do? In spite of my knavery and tricks, I was constantly upon the point of starving; and having once contracted an idle habit of eat∣ing, I never could bring myself to leave it off. After living five years by my wits, want drove me almost out of them. I knew not what course to take, when I heard that Earl Of∣mond's jester had fled the country. I exerted my knavery for the last time in stealing the fugitive's cast coat, was accept∣ed in his place by the Earl, and now gain an honest liveli∣hood by persuading my neighbours that I'm a greater fool than themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: And your change is for the better?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Infinitely; indeed your fool is univesally preferred to your knave—and for this reason; your fool is cheated, your knave cheats. Now every body had rather cheat than be cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Some truth in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: And now, Sir, may I ask, what brings you to Wales?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: A woman, whom I adore.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Yes, I guessed that the business was about a petti∣coat. And this woman is—

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: The orphan ward of a villager, without friends, without family, without fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Great points in her favour, I must confess. And which of these excellen ualities won your heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: I hope I had better reasons for bestowing it on her. No, Gilbert; I loved her for a person beautiful with∣out art, and graceful without affectation; for an heart tender without weakness, and noble without pride. I saw her at once beloved and reverenced by her village companions: they looked on her as a being of a superior order; and I felt, that she who gave such dignity to the cottage maid, must needs add new lustre to the coronet of the Percies.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: From which I am to understand that you mean to marry this rustic.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Could I mean otherwise, I should blush for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Yet surely the baseness of her origin—

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Can to me be no objection: In giving her my hand I raise her to my station, not debase myself to her's, nor ever, while gazing on the beauty of a rose, did I think it less fair because planted by a peasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Bravo! And what says your good grumbling fa∣ther to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Alas! he has long slept in the grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Then he's quiet at last! Well, God grant him that peace in heaven, which he suffered nobody to enjoy on earth! But, his death having left you master of your ac∣tions, what obstacle now prevents your marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: You shall hear. Fearful lest my rank should in∣fluence this lovely girl's affections, and induce her to bestow her hand on the noble, while she refused her heart to the man, I assumed a peasant's habit, and presented myself as Edwy the low-born and the poor. In this character I gain∣ed her heart, and resolved to hail, as Countess of Northum∣berland, the betrothed of Edwy the low-born and the poor!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: I warrant the pretty soul wasn't displeased with the discovery!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: That discovery is still unmade. Judge how great must have been my disappointment, when, on entering her guardian's cottage with this design, he informed me, that the unknown, who sixteen years before had confided her to his care, had reclaimed her on that very morning, and convey∣ed her no one knew whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: That was unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Was it not? Ah! had I declared myself one day sooner, ere this she would have been my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: True; and being your wife, if a stranger then had conveyed her no one knew whith you might have thought yourself mightily obliged to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: However, in spite of his precautions, I have traced the stranger's course, and find him to be Kenric, a de∣pendant upon Earl Osmond.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Surely 'tis not Lady Angela, who—

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: The very same! Speak, my good fellow, do you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Not by your description; for here she's under∣stood to be the daughter of Sir Malcolm Mowbray, my mas∣ter's deceased friend. And what is your present intention?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: To demand her of the Earl in marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Oh! that will never do; for in the first place you'll not be able to get a sight of him. I've now lived with him five long years, and, till Angela's arrival, never witnessed a guest in the Castle. Oh! 'tis the most melancholy man∣sion! And as to its master, he's the very antidote to mirth. He always walks with his arms folded, his brows bent, his eyes lowering on you with a gloomy scowl. He never smiles; and to laugh in his presence would be high treason. He looks at no one, speaks to no one. None dare approach him, except Kenric and his four blacks; all others are or∣dered to avoid him; and whenever he quits his room, ding∣dong goes a great bell, and away run the servants like so many scared rabbits.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Strange! and what reasons can he have for—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Oh! reasons in plenty. You must know there's an ugly story respecting the last owners of this Castle. Os∣mond's brother, his wife, and infant child, were murdered by a banditti, as it was said. Unluckily, the only servant who escaped the slaughter, deposed, that he recognized among the assassins a black still in the service of Earl Osmond. The truth of this assertion was never known, for the servant was found dead in his bed the next morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Good heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Since that time, no sound of joy has been heard in Conway Castle. Osmond instantly became gloomy and fe∣rocious; he now never utters a sound except a sigh, has broken every tie of society, and keeps his gates barred un∣ceasingly against the stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Yet Angela is admitted: But, no doubt, affec∣tion for her father—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Why, no; I rather think that affection for her fa∣ther's child—

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: If I've any knowledge in love, the Earl feels it for his fair ward: But the lady will tell you more of this, if I can procure for you an interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: The very request which—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P:
'Tis no easy matter, I promise you; but I'll do
my best. In the meanwhile, wait for me in yonder fishing∣hut; its owner's name is Edric: tell him that I sent you, and he will give you a retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Farewel, then; and remember that whatever re∣ward—

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Dear master, to mention a reward insults me. You have already shown me kindness; and when 'tis in my pow∣er to be of use to you, to need the inducement of a second favour would prove me a scoundrel undeserving of the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: How warm is this good fellow's attachment! Yet our Barons complain that the great can have no friends! If they have none, let their own pride ar the blame. Instead of looking with scorn on those whom a smile would attract, and a favour bind forever, how many firm friends might our nobles gain, if they would but reflect that their vassals are men as they are, and have hearts whose feelings can be grateful as their own.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Now, Hassan, what success?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: My search has been fruitless. In vain have I paced the river's banks, and pierced the grove's deepest recesses. Nor glen nor thicket have I passed unexplored, yet found no stranger to whom Kenric's description could apply.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Saw you no one?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: A troop of horsemen passed me as I left the wood.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Horsemen, say you? then Kenric may be right. Earl Percy has discovered Angela's abode, and lurks near the Castle in hopes of carrying her off.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: His hopes then will be vain. Osmond's vigilance will not easily be eluded, sharpened by those powerful mo∣tives, love and fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: His love I know; but should he lose Angela, what has he to fear?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P:
If Percy gains her, every thing! Supported by such wealth and power, dangerous would be her claim to these domains should her birth be discovered. Of this our Lord is aware; nor did he sooner hear that Northumberland loved her, than he hastened to remove her from Allan's
care. At first I doubt his purpose was a foul one: her resemblance to her mother induced him to change it. He now is resolved to make her his bride, and restore to her those rights of which himself deprived her.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Think you the lady perceives that our master loves her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: I know she does not. Absorbed in her own pas∣sion for Percy, on Osmond's she bestows no thought; and, while roving through these pompous halls and chambers, sighs for the Cheviot hills, and Allan's humble cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: But as she still believes Percy to be a low-born swain, when Osmond days his coronet at her feet, will she reject his rank and splendor?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: If she loves well, she will. Saib, I too have loved! I have known how painful it was to leave her on whom my heart hung! how incapable was all else to supply her loss! I have exchanged want for plenty, fatigue for rest, a wretched hut for a splendid palace. But am I happier? Oh! no! Still do I regret my native land, and the partners of my poverty. Then toil was sweet to me, for I laboured for Samba; then repose ever blest my bed of leaves, for there by my side lay Samba sleeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: This from you, Hassan?—Did love ever find a place in your flinty bosom?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: Did it? Oh Saib; my heart once was gentle, once was good! But sorrows have broken it—insults have made it hard! I have been dragged from my native land! from a wife who was every thing to me, to whom I was every thing! Twenty years have elapsed since these Christ∣ians tore me away; they trampled upon my heart, mocked my despair; and, when in frantic terms I raved of Samba, laughed, and wondered how a negro's soul could feel! In that moment, when the last point of Africa faded from my view, when as I stood on the vessel's deck, I felt that all I loved was to me lost forever! In that bitter moment did I banish humanity from my breast! I tore from my arm the bracelet of Samba's hair, I gave to the sea the precious token, and, while the high waves swift bore it from me, vowed aloud endless hatred to mankind. I have kept my oath, and I will keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Ill-starred Hassan! your wrongs have indeed been great.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: To remember them, un-mans me—Farewel! I must to Kenric. Hold!—Look, where he comes from Osmond's chamber!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: And seemingly in wrath.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: His conferences with the Earl of late have had no other end. The period of his favour is arrived.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Not of his favour merely, Hassan.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: How? Mean you that—

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: His anxiety for independence, his wish to withdraw himself from Wales—yet more, certain mysterious words and threats for some time past have made our Lord uneasy. By him was I this morning commissioned—Silence! He's here, you shall know more anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: His promise ever evaded! My request still heard with impatience, and treated with neglect! Osmond, I will bear your ingratitude no longer.—Now, Hassan, found you the man described?

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: Nor any that resembled him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Yet, that I saw Percy, I am convinced. As I crossed him in the wood, his eye met mine. He started as had he seen a basilisk, and fled with rapidity. Be on your guard, my friends; doubtless he will attempt to gain admis∣sion to the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Hass.
SP.P: Can we be otherwise than watchful, when we see how well the Earl rewards his followers?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Of that, Kenric, you are an example. Have you obtained that recompense so long promised? Do you enjoy that independence which—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Saib, the Earl's ingtatitude cuts me to the heart! Attached to him from his infancy, I have long been his friend, long fancied him mine: The illusion is now over. He sees that I can serve him no further—knows that I can harm him much; therefore he fears, and, fearing, hates me. But I will submit no longer to this painful depedence. To-morrow, for the last time, will I summon him to perform his promise; if he refuses, I will bid him farewel forever! and, by my absence, free him from a restraint equally irksome to myself and him.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Will you so, Kenric? Be speedy then, or you will be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Too late! And wherefore?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: You will soon receive the reward of your services.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Ha! Know you what that reward will be?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: I guess, but may not tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Is it a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Can you keep one?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Faithfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: As faithfully can I. Come, Hassan.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: What meant the slave? Those doubt∣ful expressions....... Ha! should the Earl intend me false...... Kenric! Kenric! how is thy nature changed! There was a time when fear was a stranger to my bosom—when, guiltless myself, I dreaded not art in others. Now, where'er I turn me, danger appears to lurk; and I suspect treachery in every breast, because my own heart hides it.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Nonsense! You silly woman, what you say is not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: I never said it was possible; I only said it was true; and that if ever I heard music, I heard it last night.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Perhaps the fool was singing to the servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: The fool indeed? Oh, fye! fye! How dare you call my Lady's ghost a fool?

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Your Lady's ghost! you silly old woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Yes, Father, yes, I repeat it; I heard the guittar, lying upon the Oratory table, play the very air which the Lady Evelina used to sing while rocking her little daughter's cradle. She warbled it so sweetly—and ever at the close it went.

LG.L: "Lullaby! Lullaby! hush thee, my dear!
"Thy father is coming, and soon will be here!"

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Nonsense! nonsense! Why, pr'ythee, Alice, do you think that your Lady's ghost would get up at night, only to sing Lullaby for your amusement? Besides, how should a spirit, which is nothing but air, play upon an instru∣ment of material wood and cat-gut?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P:
How can I tell? Why, I know very well that men are made; but if you desired me to make a man, I vow and protest I shouldn't know how to set about it. I can on¦ly
say, that last night I heard the ghost of my murdered Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Playing upon the spirit of a cracked guittar! Alice! Alice! these fears are ridiculous! The idea of ghosts is a vulgar prejudice; and they who are timid and absurd enough to encourage it, prove themselves the most contemptible—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Oh! Lord bless us!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: What!—Hey!—Oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Look! look! A figure in white! It comes from the haunted room!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Blessed St. Patrick!—Who has got my beads? Where's my prayer-book?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: It comes! it comes!—Now! now!—Lack-a-day, it's only Lady Angela!
Lack-a-day! I'm glad of it with all my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Truly, so am I. But what say you now, Father, to the fear of spectres?

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: In good faith, Alice, that my theory was bet∣ter than my practice. However, the next time that you are afraid of a ghost, remember and make use of the receipt which I shall now give you; and instead of calling for a priest to lay the spirits of other people in the red sea, call for a bottle of red wine to raise your own, Probatum est.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Wine indeed!—I believe he thinks I like drinking as well as himself. No, no! Let the old toping friar take his bottle of wine; I shall confine myself to plain cherry-brandy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I am weary of wandering from room to room; in vain do I change the scene; discontent is every where. There was a time when music could delight my ear, and nature could charm my eye;—when, as the dawn unveiled the land∣scape, each object it disclosed to me looked pleasant and fair; and while the last sun-beams yet lingered on the western sky, I could pour forth a prayer of gratitude, and thank my good angels for a day unclouded by sorrow!—Now all is gone, all lost, all faded!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P:
Perhaps at this moment he thinks upon me! Per∣haps
he wanders on those mountains where we so oft have strayed, reclines on that bank where we so oft have sat, or listens sadly to the starling which he taught to repeat my name. Perhaps then he sighs; and murmurs to himself: The flowers, the rivulets, the birds, every object reminds me of my well-beloved; but what shall remind her of Edwy?—Oh! that will my heart, Edwy; I need no other remembrancer!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Lady! Lady Angela!—She minds me no more than a post!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Oh! are you there, good Alice? What would you with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Only ask how your Ladyship rested?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Ill! very ill!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Lack-a-day! and yet you sleep in the best bed!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: True, good Alice; but my heart's anguish strewed thorns upon my couch of down.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Marry, I'm not surprised that you rested ill in the Cedar-room. Those noises so near you—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: What noises? I heard none.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: How?—When the clock struck one, heard you no music?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Music!—None.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: And never have heard any while in the Cedar-room?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: No that I—Stay! now I remember that while I sat alone in my chamber this morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Well, Lady, well!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Methought I heard some one singing; it seemed as if the words run thus— [singing] "Lullaby! Lullaby! Hush thee, my dear!"

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: The very words!—It was the ghost. Lady! it was the ghost!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: The ghost, Alice!—I protest I thought it had been you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Me, Lady!—Lord, when did you hear this singing?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Not five minutes ago, while you were talking with Father Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: The Lord be thanked!—Then it was not the ghost: It was I, Lady! It was I!—And have you heard no other singing since you came to the Castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: None. But why that question?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Because, Lady — But perhaps you may be fright∣ened?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: No, no!—Proceed, I entreat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Why, then, they do say, that the chamber in which you sleep is haunted. You may have observed two folding-doors, which are ever kept locked: they lead to the Oratory, in which the Lady Evelina passed most of her time, while my Lord was engaged in the Scottish wars. She would sit there, good soul! hour after hour, playing on the lute, and singing airs so sweet, so sad, that many a time and oft have I wept to hear her. Ah! when I kissed her hand at the Castle-gate, little did I suspect that her fate would have been so wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: And what was her fate?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: A sad one, Lady! Impatient to embrace her Lord, after a year's absence, the Countess set out to meet him on his return from Scotland, accompanied by a few do∣mestics and her infant daughter, then scarce a twelvemonth old. But, as she returned with her husband, robbers surpris∣ed the party scarce a mile from the Castle; and since that time, no news has been received of the Earl, of the Countess, the servants, or the child.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Dreadful! Where not their corpses found?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Never! The only domestic who escaped, pointed out the scene of action; and as it proved to be on the river's banks, doubtless the assassins plunged the bodies into the stream.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Strange! And did Earl Osmond then become owner of this Castle?—Alice! was he ever suspected of—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Speak lower, Lady! It was said so, I own; but for my own part I never believed it. To my certain knowl∣edge, Osmond loved the Lady Evelina too well to hurt her; and when he heard of her death, he wept and sobbed as if his heart were breaking. Nay, 'tis certain that he proposed to her before marriage, and would have made her his wife, only that she liked his brother better. Well she might, in∣deed; for Earl Reginald was a sweeter gentleman by half.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: And in that Oratory, you say—Good Alice, you have the key of it: Let me see that Oratory to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: To-night, Lady? Heaven preserve me! I wouldn't enter it after dark for the world!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: But before dark, Alice?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Before dark? Why that indeed—Well, well, we'll see, Lady. But I hope you're not alarmed by what I mentioned of the Cedar-room?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: No, truly, Alice; from good spirits I have noth∣ing to fear, and Heaven and my innocence will protect me against bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: My very sentiments, I protest! But Heaven for∣give me, while I stand gossipping here, I warrant all goes wrong in the kitchen! Your pardon, Lady: I must away! I must away!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Osmond was his brother's heir. His strange demeanour!—Yes, in that gloomy brow is written a volume of villany!—Heavenly powers! an assassin then is master of my fate!—An assassin too who—I dare not bend my thoughts that way!—Oh! would I had never entered these Castle walls!—had never exchanged for fearful pomp the security of my pleasures, the tranquillity of my soul!

LG.L: Return, return, sweet peace! and o'er my breast
Spread thy bright wings, distil thy balmy rest,
And teach my steps thy realms among to rove;
Wealth and the world resign'd, nought mine but love!
Ah! cease thy suit, fond girl! thy prayer is vain,
For thus did Love his tyrant law ordain:
—"Peace still must fly that heart where I still reign."

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—The Armoury.—Suits of Armour are arranged on both Sides upon Pedestals, with the Names of their Posses∣sors written under each.

SP.P: THE coast is clear!—Hist, hist!—You may enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Loiter not here!—Quick, my good fellow, con∣duct me to Angela.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P:
Softly, softly, a little caution is needful; and I promise you just now I'm not upon roses. You remember
he servant, who hinted that Earl Osmond had an hand in his brother's murder!—Should I be suspected of admitting you to the Castle, his fate might be mine; and whatever you may think of it, my Lord, I shouldn't be at all pleased at waking to-morrow morning, to find myself dead in my bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: If such are your fears, why not lead me at once to Angela? Are we not more exposed in this open hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Be contented, and leave all to me; I will con∣trive matters so that Osmond shall have you before his eyes, and be no jot the wiser. Here, [taking down a suit of ar∣mour] put on this coat of mail; you must make up your mind to play a statue for an hour or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis absolutely necessary. Quick, quick! ere the servants quit the hall, where they are now at dinner. Here's the helmet, the gauntlet, the shield! So now take this truncheon in your hand, and there we have you armed cap a pee.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: And now be good enough to explain what pur∣pose this masquerade is to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Willingly. You are to know, that since the late Earl's death, the Castle is thought to be haunted; the ser∣vants are fully persuaded that his ghost wanders every night through the long galleries, and parades the old towers and dreary halls which abound in this melancholy mansion. He is supposed to be drest in a complete armour; and that which you wear at present was formerly his. Now hear my plan. The Earl prepares to hold a conference with Lady Angela; even now I heard her summoned to attend him in the Ar∣moury. Placed upon this pedestal, you may listen to their discourse unobserved, and thus form a proper judgment both of your mistress and her guardian. As soon as it grows dark, I will conduct you to Angela's apartments: the ob∣scurity will then shelter you from discovery; and even should you be observed, you will pass for Earl Reginald's spectre.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: I do not dislike your plan; but tell me, Gilbert, do you believe this tale of the apparition?

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P:
Oh, Heaven forbid! Not a word of it. Had I minded all the strange things related of this Castle, I should have died of fright in the first half hour. Why, they say that Earl Hubert rides every night round the Castle on a white horse; that the ghost of Lady Bertha hunts the west
pinnacle of the Chapel-Tower; and that Lord Hildebrand, who was condemned for treason some sixty years ago, may be seen in the Great Hall, regularly at midnight, playing at foot-ball with his own head! Above all, they say that the spirit of the late Countess sits nightly in her Oratory, and sings her baby to sleep. However, if it be so— [A bell sounds thrice, loud and solemn]—Hark! 'tis the Earl! Quick to your post! [Percy ascends the pedestal] Farewel!I must get out of his way; but as soon as he quits this chamber, I'll rejoin you.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Do so; and farewel.

DIV3.STAGE: [The folding doors are thrown open: SAIB, HASSAN, MU∣LEY, and ALARIC enter, preceding Earl OSMOND, who walks with his arms folded, and his eyes bent upon the ground. SAIB advances a sofa, into which, after making a few turns through the room, OSMOND throws himself. He motions to his attendants, and they withdraw. He appears lost in thought; then suddenly rises, and again traverses the room with disordered steps.]

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
I will not sacrifice my happiness to her's! For six∣teen long years have I thirsted; and now, when the cup of joy again stands full before me, shall I dash it from my lip? No, Angela, you ask of me too much. Since the moment when I pierced her heart, deprived of whom life became odi∣ous; since my soul was stained with his blood who loved me, with her's whom I loved, no form has been grateful to my eye, no voice spoken pleasure to my soul, save Angela's, save only Angela's! Doating upon one whom death has long clasped in his arms; tortured by desires which I never hop∣ed to satisfy, many a mournful year has my heart known no throb but of anguish, no guest but remorse at committing a fruitless crime. Hope, that stranger, once more visits my bosom: the fiend, who led me through passion's mazes to the heights of guilt, owns that a crime so great well merits a reward. He bids the monument's jaws unclose: Evelina revives in her daughter, and soon shall the fires which con∣sume me be quenched in Angela's arms. What though her heart be Percy's? What though she prefer a basilisk's kiss to mine? Because my short-lived joy may cause her eternal sorrow, shall I reject those pleasures sought so long, desired so earnestly? That will I not, by Heaven! Mine she is,
and mine she shall be, though Reginald's bleeding ghost flit before me, and thunder in my ear—"Hold! hold!"—Peace, stormy heart! She comes!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Come hither, Angela. Where∣fore so sad? That downcast eye, that listless air, neither suit your age or fortunes. Raised from obscurity to rank and splendour, can this change call no smile upon your cheek? Where'er you turn, respect and adoration wait you; a thou∣sand servants move obedient to your nod. The treasures of India are lavished to adorn your person; yet still do I see you, forgetting what you are, look back with regret to what you were!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Oh! my good Lord, esteem me not ungrateful! I acknowledge your bounties, but they have not made me hap∣py. I still linger in thought near those scenes where I pass∣ed the blessed period of infancy; I still thirst for those sim∣ple pleasures which habit has made to me most dear. The birds which my own hands reared, and the flowers which my own hands planted; the banks on which I rested when fatigued, the wild tangled wood which supplied me with strawberries, and the village church where I prayed to be virtuous, while I yet knew of vice and virtue but the name, all have acquired rights to my memory and my love!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: What? these costly dresses, these scenes of pomp and greatness—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Dazzle my eyes, but leave my heart unsatisfied. What I would meet with is affection, not respect; I had rather be obliged than obeyed; and all these glittering gems are far less dear to me, than one flower of a wreath which Edwy's hands have woven.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: While I saw you, Cheviot Hills, I was happy, Oh! how happy! While I listened to your artless accents, friends of my childhood, how swelled my fond heart with gratitude and pleasure! At morn, when I left my bed, light were my spirits, and gay as the zephyrs of summer; and when at night my head again pressed my pillow, I whis∣pered to myself, "Happy has been to-day, and to-morrow will be as happy!" Then sweet was my sleep; and my dreams were of those whom I loved dearest.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Romantic enthusiast! these thoughts did well fo the village maid, but disgrace the daughter of Sir Malcolm Mowbray: Let them be changed for others, better suited to your birth, to the fortune which awaits you. Hear me Angela; an English Baron loves you, a nobleman tha whom our island boasts few more potent. 'Tis to him that your hand is destined; 'tis on him that your heart must be bestowed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I cannot dispose of that which has long been anoth∣er's. My heart is Edwy's.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Edwy's? A peasant's?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: For the obscurity of his birth, chance must be blam∣ed; the merit of his virtues belongs wholly to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: By Heaven, you seem to think that poverty is a virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Sir, I think 'tis a misfortune, not a crime: And witen in-spite of nature's injustice, and the frowns of a preju∣diced and illiberal world, I see some low-born but illustrious spirit prove itself superior to the station which it fills, I hail it with pleasure, with admiration, with respect! Such a spirit I found in Edwy, and, finding, loved.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: My blood boils with passion!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: You say, that by these sentiments I disgrace my rank: I say, that to break my given word, would disgrace it more. Edwy has my plighted faith: He received it on the last evening which I passed in Northumberland, as we sat on alow bench before old Allan's cottage. It was an heavenly night, sweet and tranquil as the loves of angels: A gentle breeze whispered 'among the honeysuckles which bloomed above us, and the full moon tinged with her silver light the distant towers of Alnwick. It was then that for the first time I gave him my hand, and swore that I never would give it but to him: It was then that for the first time he pressed his lips to mine, and I swore that my lips should nev∣er be pressed by another!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Girl! girl! you drive me to distraction!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: You alarm me, my Lord! Permit me to retire.
SP.STAGE: Going, Osmond detains her violently by the arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Stay!— [In a softer tone.] Angela, I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
Love you to madness!—My bos∣om is a gulph of devouring flames! I must quench them in
your arms, or perish!—Nay, strive not to escape; remain and hear me! I offer you my hand; if you accept it, mis∣tress of these fair and rich domains, your days shall glide away in happiness and honour; but if you refuse, and scorn my offer, force shall this instant—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Force? Oh, no!—You dare not be so base!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Reflect on your situation, Angela: You are in my power—remember it, and be wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: If you have a generous mind, that will be my sur∣est safeguard. Be it my plea, Osmond, when thus I sue to you for mercy, for protection! Look on me with pity, Os∣mond: 'Tis the daughter of the man you loved; 'tis a crea∣ture, friendless, wretched and forlorn, who kneels before you, who flies to you for refuge! True, I am in your pow∣er: Then fave me, respect me, treat me not cruelly; for—I am in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: I will hear no more. Will you accept my ofer?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Osmond, I conjure you—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Answer my question!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Mercy! Mercy!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Will you be mine?—Speak! Speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.STAGE: [After a moment's pause, rises, and pronounces with firmness.]
SP.P: Never—so help me Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Your fate then is decided!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Hold!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Ha! What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Hark! hark!—Heard you not a voice?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
It came from hence!—From Reginald!—Was it not a delusion?—Did indeed his spirit— [Relapsing into his former passion.] Well, be it so! Though his ghost should rush between us, thus would I clasp her—Horror! What sight is this?— [At the moment that he again seines Angela, Percy extends his truncheon with a me∣nacing gesture, and descends from the pedestal. Osmond releas∣es Angela, who immediately rushes from the chamber, while Per∣cy advances a few steps, and remains gazing on the Earl sted∣fastly]—I know that shield!—that helmet!—Speak to me, dreadful vision!—Tax me with my crimes!—Tell me, that you come—Stay! Speak!— [Following Percy, who, when
he reaches the door, through which Angela escaped, turns, and signs to him with his hand. Osmond starts back in terror.]—He forbids my following!—He leaves me!—The door closes— [In a sudden burst of passion, and drawing his sword]—Hell and fiends! I'll follow him, though lightnings blast med—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Here's rudeness! Here's ill-breeding! On my conscience, this house grows worse and worse every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: What can he have done with himself? Perhaps weary of waiting for me in the Armoury, he has found his way alone to Angela. How now, dame Alice, what has happened to you? You look angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: By my troth, fool, I've little reason to look pleas∣ed. To be frightened out of my wits by night, and thump∣ed and bumped about by day, is not likely to put one in the best humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Poor soul! And who has been thumping and bumping you?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Who has? You should rather ask who has not.—Why only hear:—As I was just now going along the nar∣row passage which leads to the Armoury—singing to myself, and thinking of nothing, I met Lady Angela flying away as if for dear life!—So I dropp'd her a courtsey—but might as well have spared my pains. Without minding me any more than if I had been a dog or a cat, she pushed me on one side; and before I could recover my balance, somebody else, who came bouncing by me, gave me t'other thump—and there I lay sprawling upon the floor. However, I tumbled with all possible decency; and took great care that my petticoats should cover my legs.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Somebody else! What somebody else?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: I know not; but he seemed to be in armour.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: In armour? Pray, Alice, looked he like a ghost?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P:
What he looked like, I cannot say; but I'm sure he didn't feel like one. However, you've not heard the worst. While I was sprawling upon the ground, my Lord
comes tearing along the passage—The first thing he did was to stumble against me—away went his heels—over he came—and in the twinkling of an eye there lay his Lordship! As soon as he got up again—Mercy? how he stormed!—He snatched me up; caled me anugly old witch; shook the breath out of my body—then clapped me on the ground again, and bounced away after the other two!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: My mind misgives me!. But what-can this mean, Alice?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: The meaning I neither know, or care about; but this I know—I'll stay no longer in an house where I'm treat∣ed so disrespectfully. "My Lady!"—says I—"Out of my way!"—says she, and pushes me on one side. "My Lord,"—says I—"You be damn'd!"—says he, and pushes me on t'other! I protest I never was so ill used, even when I was a young woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: This account alarms me!—Should Percy be dis∣covered—The very thought gives me a creak in my neck! At any rate, I had better inquire whether—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Get out of the house!—That's your way.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Why, what's the meaning—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Don't stand prating here; but do as I bid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: But first tell me—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: I can only tell you to get out of the house. Kenric has discovered Earl Percy—You are known to have introduced him—The Africans are in search of you: If you are found, you will be hung out of hand. Fly then to Edric's cottage; hide yourself there. Hark!—Some one comes! Away, away, ere it is too late!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: But Earl Percy—But Angela—

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Leave them to me. You shall hear from me soon. Only take care of yourself, and fly with all diligence!—Away!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P:
So, so, he's off, and now I've time to take breath. I've not moved so nimbly for the last twenty years; and, in truth, I'm at present but ill calculated for ve∣locity of motion. However, my exertions have not been throv away: I've saved this poor knave from Osmond's ven∣geance—and should my plan, for the Lady's release, succeed—Poor little soul!—To see how she took on, when Percy was
torn from her! Well, well, she shall be rescued from her ty∣rant. The moveable pannels—the subterraneous passages—the secret springs are well known to me—Oh! I cannot fail of success: But in order to secure it, I'll finally arrange my ideas in the Buttery. Whenever I've any great design in hand, I always ask advice of a flaggon of ale, and mature my plan over a cold venison pasty. Oh! what an excellent ge∣nius must that man have had, who first invented eating and drinking!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—A spacious Chamber: On one Side is a Couch: On the other a Table, which is placed under an arched and lofty Window.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter OSMOND, followed by SAIB, HASSAN, MULEY, and ALARIC, who conduct PERCY, disarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: This, Sir, is your prison; but, doubtless, your con∣finement will not continue long. The moment which gives me Angela's hand, shall restore you to liberty; and, till that moment arrives, farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Stay, Sir, and hear me!—By what authority pre∣sume you to call me captive?—Have you forgotten that you speak to Northumberland's Earl?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Well may I forget him, who could so far forget him∣self. Was it worthy of Northumberland's Earl to steal dis∣guised into my Castle, and plot with my servant to rob me of my most precious treasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Mine was that treasure. You deprived me of it basely, and I was justified in striving to regain my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Earl, nothing can justify unworthy means. If you were wronged, why sought you not your right with your sword's point? I then should have esteemed you a noble foe; and as such would have treated you: But you have stooped to paltry artisice, and attacked me like some midnight ruffian, privately, and in disguise. By this am I authorized to forget your station, and make your penance as degrading as your offence was base.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: If such are indeed your sentiments, prove them now. Restore my sword, unsheathe your own, and be An∣gela the conqueror's reward!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
No, Earl Percy!—I am not so rash a gamester as to suffer that cast to be recalled, by which the stake is mine
already. Angela is in my power: The only man who could wrest her from my arms has wilfully made himself my cap∣tive: Such he is, and such he shall remain.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Insulting tyrant! Your cowardice in refusing my challenge proves sufficiently—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Be calm, Earl Percy!—You forget yourself. That I am no coward, my sword has proved in the fields of Scot∣land. My sword shall again prove it, if, when you are re∣stored to liberty, you still question the courage of my heart! Angela once mine, repeat your defiance, nor doubt my an∣swering.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Angela thine?—That she shall never be! There are angels above who favour virtue, and the hour of retribu∣tion must one day arrive.—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: But long ere the arrival of that hour shall Angela have been my bride; and now farewel, Lord Percy!—Muley and Saib!

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: To your charge I commit the Earl. Quit not this apartment, nor suffer him for one moment from your sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib and Muley.
SP.P: My Lord, we shall obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: If she refuse me still, the death of this, her favourite—his death! Oh! through what bloody paths do I wander in pursuit of happiness! Yes, I am guilty! Heaven! how guilty! Yet lies the fault with me? Did my own pleas∣ure plant in my bosom these tempestuous passions? No! they were given me at my birth; they were sucked in with my ex∣istence. Nature formed me the slave of wild desires; and Fate, as she frowned upon my cradle, exclaimed; "I doom this babe to be a villain and a wretch!"

DIV3.STAGE: [Exit, followed by Hassan and Alaric, who lock the door after them.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Look, Muley, how bitterly he frowns.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Now he starts from the sofa! Faith, he's in a monstrous fuy.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: That may well be: When you mean to take in oth∣er people, it certainly is provoking to be taken in yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.STAGE: [After walking a few turns with a disordered air, suddenly stops.]
SP.P: H gone to Angela! Gone, perhaps, to renew that outrage ose completion my presence alone pre∣vented. Hloless and unprotected, with no friend but inno∣cence—no cates save tears—how will she now repel his violence?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Now he's in a deep study: Marry, if he studies himself out of this tower, he's a cleverer fellow than I take him for.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Were I not Osmond's captive, all might yet be well. Summoning my vassals, who by this time must be near at hand, forcing the Castle, and tearing Angela from the arms of her tyrant! Alas! my captivity has rendered my plan impracticable! Eternal curses upon Gilbert, who persuaded me to adopt this artifice! Curses on my own rash folly, which has thrown me defenceless in the power of my foe!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: That's right—Another stamp or two, and the Tower comes rattling about our ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: And are there then no hopes of liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: He fixes his eyes on us.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Might not these fellows—I can but try. Now stand my friend, thou master-key to human hearts! Aid me, thou potent devil, gold! Hear me, my worthy friends! Come nearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: His worthy friends! Are we such, Muley?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Yes, truly are we; for friends in need are friends indeed: Marry, if he were not in need, he would call us his mortal foes.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: My good fellows, you are charged with a disa∣greeable office, and to obey a tyrant's mandates cannot be pleasant to you; there is something in your looks which has prejudiced me too much in your favour to believe it possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Nay, there certainly is something in our appear∣ance highly prepossessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: And I know that you must admire the delicacy of our complexions!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: The tincture of your skin, my good fellow, is of little consequence: Many a worthy heart heats within a dusky bosom, and I am convinced that such an heart inhab∣its your's; for your looks tell me that you feel for, and are anxious to relieve, my sufferings. See you this purse, my friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: It's too far off, and I'm short-sighted. If you'll put it a little nearer—

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Restore me to liberty! and not this purse alone, but ten times its value shall be your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: To liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: That purse?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Muley.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Saib!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: By all my hopes, they hesitate! You well know, that my wealth and power are equal, not to say superior, to Earl Osmond's: Release me from my dungeon, and share that power and wealth! On the events of to-day depend my life's future happiness, nay, perhaps my life itself. Judge, then, if you assist me, how great will be the service rendered me, and believe that your reward shall equal my obligation.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: I know not what to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: In truth, my Lord, your offers are so generous, and that purse is so tempting—Saib, what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: The Earl speaks so well, and promises so largely, that I own I'm strangely tempted.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Look you, Saib—will you stand by me?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: I will!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: There's my hand, then. My Lord, we are your servants!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: This is beyond my hopes! A thousand thanks, my worthy fellows! Be assured that the performance of my promises shall soon follow the execution of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Of that we make no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: You agree, then, to release me?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible to do otherwise; for I feel that pity, generosity, and every moral feeling command me to trouble your Lordship for that purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: There it is! And now unlock the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Here it is! And now I'm obliged to you. As for your promises, my Lord, pray don't trouble yourself to remember them, as I sha'n't trouble my∣self to remember mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Ha! What mean you?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Earl, that we are faithful!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: I wonder you didn't read that too in our amiable looks!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: What! Will you not keep your word?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: In good truth, no; we mean to keep nothing—except the purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Perfidious villains▪

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: You mistake us, Sir; we cannot be villains; for I, you know, am your Lordship's "worthy friend!"

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: And I your Lordship's unworthy pensioner!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Confusion!—To be made the jest of such rascals!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Earl Percy, we are none; but we should have been, could your gold have bribed us to betray our master. We have but done our duty; you have but gained your just reward; for they who seek to deceive others, should ever be deceived themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Silence, fellow!—Leave me to my thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Oh! with all our hearts! We ask no better.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Muley, we share that purse?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Undoubtedly: Sit down, and examine its con∣tents.
SP.STAGE: [They seat themselves on the floor in the front of the stage.]

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: How unfortunate, that the only merit of these villains should be fidelity! No hope now is left! Angela is lost, and with her my happiness!

DIV3.STAGE: CHORUS OF VOICES. [Singing without.] "Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!"

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Hark! What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: I'll see. [Mounting upon the table.] This window is so high—

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Here, here! Take this chair.
SP.STAGE: [Saib places the chair upon the table, and thus lifts himself to a level with the window, which he opens.]

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Sleep you, or wake you, Lady bright?

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl. — — —
SP.P: Now is the fittest time for flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Chor. — — —
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl. — — —
SP.L: Know, from your tyrant's farther power,
Beneath the window of your tower,
A boat now waits to set you free;

SP.SPEAKER: Chor. — — — —
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.STAGE: [Who has half raised himself from the couch during the latter part of the Song, and listened attentively.]
SP.P: Surely I know that voice!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Now, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: A boat lies at the foot of the tower, and the fisher∣men sing while they draw their nets.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: I could not be mistaken—It was Gilbert!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Hark! They begin again!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Though deep the stream, though high the wall,

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: The danger, trust me, Love, is small:

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.L: To spring below then, never dread;
My arms to catch you shall be spread;
And far from hence you soon shall be,

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: I understand him. He bids me—Yet the dan∣ger—What course shall I pursue?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, come down, Saib; I long to divide the purse—

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Stay a moment: one more stanza, and I'm with you. Now, silence!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: Fair Emma hush'd her heart's alarms:

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.P: She sprang into her Lover's arms:

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Motl.
SP.L: Unhurt she fell; then swift its way
While Emma, plac'd on Edgar's knee,

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.P: Sing Megen-oh! Oh! Megen-Ee!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Will you never quit that window?

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Here I am, and now for the purse.
SP.STAGE: [They resume their seats upon the ground; Saib opens the purse, and begins to reckon the gold.]

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: Yes, I must brave the danger. I will feign to sleep; and when my gaolers are off their guard, then aid me, blest Providence!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Hold, Muley! What if, instead of sharing the purse, we throw for its contents? Here are dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: With all my heart—And look! to pass our time the better, here's a bottle of the best sack in the Earl's cellar.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Good! good! And now, be this angel the stake—But first, what is our prisoner doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Oh! he sleeps: Mind him not. Come, come—Throw!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Here goes—Nine!—Now to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Nine too!—Double the stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Agreed! and the throw is mine. Hark! What noise!
SP.STAGE: [Duri this dialogue, Perey has approached the ta∣ble in silence—At the moment he prepares to mount it, Saib looks round, and Percy hastily throws himself back upon the couch.]

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Oh! nothing, nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Methought I heard the Earl—

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Mere fancy: You see he is sleeping soundly Come, come—Throw!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: There, then—Elven!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: That's bad—Huzza!—Sixes!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Plague on your fortune!—Come, double or quits.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Be it so, and I throw.—Zounds! Only five!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Then I think this hit must be mine.—Aces, by heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—Your health, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.STAGE: [Who has again reached the table, mounted the chair, and, opening the window, now stands at it, and signs to the men below.]
SP.P: They see me, and extend a cloth beneath the win∣dow!—'Tis a fearful height!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Do you mean to empty the bottle? Come, come—Give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Muley.
SP.P: Take it, blunder-head!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy.
SP.P: They encourage me to venture!—Now then, or never! [Aloud.] Angels of bliss, protect me!

SP.SPEAKER: Muley and Said
SP.P: Hell and furies!

SP.STAGE: [Dashes down the bottle, and climbs to the window has∣tily, while Muley remains below in an attitude of surprize.]
SP.P: Escaped! Escaped!

SP.SPEAKER: Percy, Motley, &c.
SP.P: Huzza! huzza! huzza!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—The Castle Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P:
YONDER he stalks, and seems buried in himself. Now then to attack him while my late service is still fresh upon his memory. Should he reject my petition positively,
he shall have good cause to repent his ingratitude. Percy is in the neighbourhood; and that secret, known only to myself, will surely—but, silence! Look where he comes!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: It shall not be! Away with these foreboding terrors which weigh down my heart! Does not all smile upon my fortunes? my rival wears my chains, he cannot wrest her from me; and, with to-morrow's dawn, Angela shall be mine. Bound then high, my heart! Pleasure, sweet guest, so long a stranger, Oh to my bosom welcome once more! I will forget the past, and enjoy the present, and make those raptures again mine, which—Ah! no, no, no!—Con∣science, that serpent, winds her folds around the cup of my bliss, and, ere my lips can reach it, her venom is mingled with the draught.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: How profound the gloom which obscures his brow!—How fixed, how hopeless glares his dark eye-ball!—Oh! dreadful is the villain's look when he ponders on committed crimes!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Evening approaches fast. [Drawing near and opening the window.] Already the air breathes cooler, and the beams of the setting fun sparkle on the waters of Conway. How fair, how tranquil all without! How dark, how comfortless all within! Hark! the sound of music!—The peasants are returning from labour: they move with gay and careless steps, carolling as they go some rustic ditty; and will pass the night in rest, for they have passed the day in innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS
SP.L: Pleased the toils of day to leave,
Home we haste with footsteps light:
Oh! how gay the cotter's eve!
Oh! how calm the cotter's night!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Curses upon them—I will look, I will listen no more! I sicken at the sight of happiness, which I never more must enjoy: I hate the possessors of hearts untainted—hate, for I envy!—Oh! fly from my eyes, bright day! Speed thy pace, darkness! thou art my love! haste to unfold thy sable mantle, and robe the world in the colour of my soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Now then to accost him—yet I tremble!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
Anguish! endless, hopeless anguish! Day or night, no moment of rest. When I sleep, dreams of strange horror
still fright me from my couch! When I wake, I find in every object some cause for distrust—read the dread charge in every eye, "thou art a murderer!" and tremble, lest the agents of my guilt should work its punishment. And see where he walks, the chief object of my fears—he shall not be so long! His anxiety to leave me, his late mysterious threats—No, no, I will not live in fear.—Soft!—he advances!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: So melancholy, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Aye, Kenric, and must be so, till Angela is mine. Know, that even now, she extorted from me a promise, that till to-morrow I would leave her unmolested.

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: But till to-morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: But till to-morrow? Oh! in that little space a lover's eye views myriads of dangers! Yet think not good Kenric, that your late services are undervalued by me, or that I have forgotten those for which I have long been your debtor. When, bewildered by hatred of Reginald, and grief for Evelina's loss, my dagger was placed on the throat of their infant, your hand arrested the blow—judge then how grateful I must feel, when I behold in Angea her mother's living counterpart—behold her such, as when shielding with her body her fallen husband, Evelina received that dagger in her breast, which I aimed at the heart of Reginald—Worthy Kenric, how can I repay your services?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: These you may easily: but what, Earl Osmond, what can repay me for the sacrifice of my innocence? I was virtuous till you bade me be guilty; my hands were pure till you taught me to stain them with blood! You painted in strong colours the shame of servitude—you promised free∣dom, riches, independence—you vanquished the resistance of my better angel, and never since have I known one mo∣ment of rest!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Good Kenric—

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: All here reminds me of my guilt—every object recalls to mind Reginald and his murdered Lady!—Let me then claim that independence so long promised, and seek for peace in some other climate, since memory forbids me to taste it in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P:
Kenric, ere named, your wish was granted. In a far distant country a retreat is already prepared for you; there may you hush those clamours of conscience, which
must reach me, I fear, even in the arms of Angela. Yet do not leave me till she is my bride; stay yet a week in Conway Castle; and then, though it will cost me many a∣pang, Kenric, you shall bid it a long adieu.—Are you eontented?

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: My Lord!—Gratitude—Amaze∣ment—And I doubted—I suspected—Oh! my good Lord, how have I wronged your kindness!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: No more—I must not hear you. [Aside.] Shame! shame! that ever my soul should stoop to dissembling with my slave!—Kenric, farewel: Till Angela is mine, keep a strict eye on Percy; and then—

DIV3.STAGE: SAIB enters, and advances with apprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: How now? why this confusion?—why do you tremble?—Speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: My Lord!—the prisoner—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: The Prisoner?—Go on! go on!

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Pardon, my Lord, pardon! our prisoner has escaped!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Villain!—
SP.STAGE: [Wild with rage he draws his dagger, and rushes upon Saib—Kenric holds his arm.]

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Hold! hold!—What would you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Unhand me, or by Heaven—

SP.SPEAKER: Kear.
SP.P: Away! away!—Fly, fellow, fly and save your∣self!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Consider, my Lord—hap∣ly 'twas not by his keeper's fault that—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: What is't to me by whose?—Is not my rival fled?—Soon will Northumberland's guards encircle my walls, and force from me—Yet that by Heaven they shall not! No! Rather than resign her, my own hand shall give this Castle a prey to flames; then plunging with Ange∣la into the blazing gulph, I'll leave these ruins to tell poster∣ity how desperate was my love, and how dreadful my re∣venge!— [Going he stops and turns to Kenric.]—And you, who dared to rush between me and my resentment—you who cld so well succeed in saving others—now look to yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Ha! that look—that threat—Yet he seemed so kind, so grateful!—He smiled too!—Oh! there is ever danger when a villain smiles.

DIV3.STAGE: SAIB enters softly, looking round him with caution.

SP.P: Hist!—Kenric!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: How now?—What brings—

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Silence, and hear me!—You have saved my life, nor will I be ungrateful—Look at this phial!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Ha! did the Earl—

SP.SPEAKER: Saib.
SP.P: Even so: a few drops of this liquor should to∣night have flavoured your wine—you would never have drank again! Mark me then—When I offer you a goblet at supper, drop it as by accident. For this night I give you life: use it to quit the Castle; for no longer than till to∣morrow dare I disobey our Lord's commands. Farewel, and fly from Conway—You bear with you my thanks!

SP.SPEAKER: Kenr.
SP.P: Can it be possible? Is not all this a dream?—Villain! villain!—Yes, yes, I must away!—But tremble, traitor!—A bolt, of which you little think, hangs over, and shall crush you!—The keys are still in my possession—Angela shall be the partner of my flight.—My prisoner too—Yet hold! May not resentment—may not Reginald's sixteen years captivity—Oh! no! Angela shall be my advocate; and, grateful for her own, for her parent's life preserved, she can, she will obtain my pardon. Yet, should she fail, at least I shall drag down Osmond in my fall, and sweeten death's bitter cup with vengeance!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—The Cedar-Room with folding Doors in the middle, and a large antique Bed; on one Side is the Portrait of a Lady, on the other that of a Warrior armed. Both are at full length.—After a pause, the Female Portrait slides back, and Father Philip, after looking in, advances cautiously.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P:
Thus far I have proceed∣ed without danger, though not without difficulty. Yon nar∣row passage is by no means calculated for persons of my habit of body. By my Holidame, I begin to suspect that the fool is in the right! I certainly am growing corpulent.—And now, how shall I employ myself?—Sinner that I am, why did I forget my bottle of sack?—The time will pass tediously till Angela comes.—And, to complete the business, yonder is the haunted Oratory. What if the ghost should pop out on me? Blessed St. Bridget, there would be a tête-à-tête
this is a foolish fear:—'Tis yet scarce eight o'clock, and your ghosts always keep late hours; yet I don't like the idea of our being such near neighbours. If Alice says true, the apparition just now lives next door to me; but the Lord forbid that we should ever be visiting acquaint∣ance!—Would I had something to drive her out of my head! A good book now, or a bottle of sack, St. Augustine, or a cold venison pasty, would be worth its weight in gold: but in the chbers of these young girls one finds nothing good either to read, drink, or eat. Now my last patroness, the Baroness O'Drench—Ah! to hear the catalogue of her crimes was quite a pleasure, for she always confessed them over a surloin of beef, and, instead of telling a bead, swal∣lowed a bumper!—Oh! she was a worthy soul!—But hark!—Angela comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: What, Alice!—Alice, I say!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: By St. David, 'tis the Earl! I'll away as fast as I can!— [Trying to open the door]—I can't find the spring!—Lord forgive me my sins!—Where can I hide myself?—Ha! the bed!—'Tis the very thing— [Throws himself into the bed, and conceals himself under the clothes.]—Heaven grant that it mayn't break down with me; for, Oh! what a fall would be there, my countrymen!—They come!—

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: You have heard my will, Lady. Till your hand is mine, you quit not this chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: If then it must be so, welcome my eternal prison!—Yet eternal it shall not be!—My hero, my guardian-angel is at liberty! Soon shall his horn make these hateful towers tremble, and your fetters be exchanged for the arms of Percy!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Beware, beware, Angela!—Dare not before me—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P:
Before you! before the world!—Is my attach∣ment a disgrace? No! 'tis my pride; for its object is deserv∣ing. Long ere I knew him, Percy's fame was dear to me. While I still believed him the peasant Edwy, often, in his hearing, have I dwelt upon Northumberland's praise, and chid him that he spoke of our Lord so coldly! Ah! little did I think that the man then seated beside me was he whom I envied for his power of doing good, whom I loved for exerting that power so largely!—Judge then, Earl Osmond,
on my arrival here how strongly I must have felt the con∣trast!—What peasant names you his benefactor? What beg∣gar has been comforted by your bounty? What sick man preserved by your care?—Your breast is unmoved by woe, your ear is deaf to complaint, your doors are barred against the poor and wretched. Not so are the gates of Alnwic Cas∣tle; they are open as their owner's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: My hair stands on end to hear her!

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Insulting girl!—This to my face?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Nay, never bend your brows!—Shall I tremble, because you frown? Shall my eye sink, because anger flashes from your's?—No! that would ill become the bride of Northumberland.

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Amazement!—Can this be the gentle, timid Angela?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Wonder you that the worm should turn, when you trample it so cruelly?—Oh! wonder no more: Ere he was torn from me, I clasped Percy to my breast, and my heart caught a spark of that fire which flames in his unceas∣ingly!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Caught fire, Lady!—Bless me, I hope you didn't burn yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Osm.
SP.P: Silence, old crone!—I have heard you calmly, Angela; now then hear me. Twelve hours shall be allow∣ed you to reflect upon your situation: till that period is elapsed, this chamber shall be your prison, and Alice, on whose fidelity I can depend, your sole attendant. This term expired, should you still reject my hand, force shall ob∣tain for me what love denies. Speak not: I will hear noth∣ing!—I swear that to-morrow sees you mine, or undone! And, skies rain curses on me, if I keep not my oath!—Mark that, proud girl! mark it, and tremble!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Heaven be praised, he's gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Tremble, did he say?—Alas! how quickly is my boasted courage vanished! Yet I will not despair: there is a Power in heaven; there is a Percy on earth: on them will I rely to save me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: The first may, Lady; but as to the second, he'll be of no use, depend on't. Now, might I advise, you'd ac∣cept my Lord's offer. What matters it, whether the man's name be Osmond or Percy? An Earl's an Earl after all; and though one may be something richer than t'other—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Oh! silence, Alice! nor aid my tyrant's designs, Rather instruct me how to counteract them. You have in∣fluence in the Castle; assist me to escape, and be assured that Percy's gratitude and generosity—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: I help you to escape! Not for the best gown in your Ladyship's wardrobe. I tremble at the very idea of my Lord's rage; and, besides, had I the will, I've not the power. Kenric keeps the keys: we could not possibly quit the Castle without his knowledge; and if the Earl threatens to use force with you—Oh Gemni! what would he use with me, Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Threatens, Alice! I despise his threats! Ere it pillows Osmond's head, will I plunge this poniard in my bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Holy fathers!—A dagger!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Even now, as I wandered through the Armoury, my eye was attracted by its glittering handle. Look, Alice! it bears Osmond's name; and the point—

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Is rusty with blood!—Take it away, Lady! take it away!—I never see blood without fainting!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: This weapon may render me good service. But, ah! what service has it rendered Osmond! Haply 'twas this very poniard which drank his brother's blood, or which pierced the fair breast of Evelina!—Said you not, Alice, that this was her portrait?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: I did, Lady; and the likeness was counted ex∣cellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: How fair! how heavenly! What sweetness, yet what dignity, in her blue, speaking eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: No wonder that you admire her, Lady: she was as like you as one pea to another. But this morning you know I promised to show you her Oratory, and here I've brought the key. Shall I unlock the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Do so, good Alice! Haply for a moment it may abstract my thoughts from my own sorrows.
Will the old woman never be gone? I dare not discover myself in her presence.

SP.STAGE: [Having opened the folding doors, an Oratory is seen, richly ornamented with carving and painted glass: Angela and Alice enter it.]
SP.P:
This room has not been opened since my Lady's death, and every thing remains as she left it. Look,
here is her veil—her prayer-book too, in which she was read∣ing on the very night before she quitted the Castle, never to return!

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: I'm out of all patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: And that guittar!—How often have I heard her play upon that guittar! She would sit in yonder window for hours, and still she played airs so sad, so sweet—To be sure she had the finest voice that ever—
SP.STAGE: [During this speech, Angela, who at first looks round with curiosity, throws the veil carelessly ov her face; and, taking a guittar from the table, strikes a few wild and melancholy notes. Alice, whose back is towards her, turns hastily round, screams, and rushes from the Oratory. Angela casts the veil and guittar upon the table, and follows her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: What alarms you?

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Is it you, Lady? let me die if I didn't take you for the ghost! Your air, your look, your attitude, all were so like the deceased Countess, that—Well, well, I'll not enter that room again in a hurry; I protest my hand trem∣bles so, that I can hardly turn the key.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: How contagious is terror; this silly woman's ap∣prehensions have spread to my bosom, and scarce can I look round without alarm. The stillness too of evening—the wavering and mysterious light which streams through these pointed windows—And, hark! 'twas the shriek of the screech-owl, which nests in the tower above.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Ah! 'twas a sad day for me, when I heard of the dear Lady's loss! Look at that bed, Lady; that very bed was her's.

SP.SPEAKER: F. Phil.
SP.P: Was it so? Oh! ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: How often have I seen her sleeping in that bed! and oh! how like an angel she looked when sleeping! I remember that just after Earl Reginald—O Lord! didn't somebody shake the curtain?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Absurd! it was the wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P:
I declare it made me tremble. Well, as I was saying, I remember just after Earl Reginald had set out to the Scottish wars, going into her room one morning, and hearing her sob most bitterly; so advancing to the bed-side, as it might be thus—"My Lady," says I, with a low courtsey, "Isn't your Ladyship well?" so, with that she raised her
head slowly above the quilt, and, giving me a mournful look—
